results.title: Four Corners - Chief Justice
results.creator_credit: David Hardakre, Madeleine O'Dea and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Presented by Liz Jackson, this episode from the “Four Corners” series looks at the role of the Australian High Court in lawmaking. In a wide-ranging interview with former High Court Chief Justice Sir Anthony Mason, the main question answered is whether the protection of individual rights is better left in the hands of Judges or politicians.

results.title: Flowers and the wide sea. Part 2: Citizens
results.creator_credit: Tony Stevens, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The new “White Australia” halted Chinese immigration amd made life difficult for those who had already made Australia their home. Many returned to China, discouraged by regulations disqualifying Chinese from citizenship, ownership of land or business and service in the armed forces. The men who stayed were unable to bring Chinese wives and families to Australia and unlikely to marry non-Chinese. So for more than 60 years, only a shrinking Chinese community remained. When the Communists rose to power, Australia, like much of the world, refused to recognise “Red China”. China responded by lowering a “bamboo curtain” between itself and the outside world. Dismayed by the turn of events in China and effectively barred from returning there, Chinese Australians remained under suspicion in their adoptive land. Then, in the 1970s Australia recognised China and abolished discriminatory immigration policies. New immigrants arrived from China, Vietnam, Malaysia, Hong Kong and Taiwan, to makes homes in an Australia which increasingly sees itself as part of the Asia Pacific region.

results.title: Flowers and the wide sea. Pt. 1: The Sojourners
results.creator_credit: Tony Stevens, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Eric Rolls, this is the story of one of Australia’s oldest immigrant communities. The Chinese came to Australia as shepherds in the 19th century, driven from their villages by famine, was and poverty. In the 1850s thousands more arrived to seek their fortunes on the goldfields. After the goldrush some stayed in Australia to establish businesses and market gardens. By the 1870s the Chinese were growing almost three quarters of the country’s vegetable supply. In spite of the Chinese contribution to the emerging nation, anti-Chinese feeling ran high in Australia’s predominantly European community. Race riots subsided with the goldrush, but politicians and trade unionists waged campaigns aimed at blicking further Chinese immigration. After Australia’s federation in 1901, the first Act of the new Australian Parliament (the white Australia Policy) prevented the entry of more Chinese.

results.title: More than words
results.creator_credit: Marvin Dreyer, Henry Strauss and Henry Strauss Productions
results.brief_description: Describes some simple techniques for good communication, to the end that people may know where they stand with one another. Illustrates how failure to give clear instructions can cause misunderstandings, trouble and dissatisfaction to those receiving the instructions.

results.title: Mirror of Germany. No. 108 = Deutschland Spiegel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mirror of Germany. The German Scene = Deutschland Spiegel”.
Magazine items: Attractions of the Hannover gardens include open air theatre, a baroque festival of the seasons and fireworks; Chancellor on holiday; new tall Bayer building commemorates centenary of the firm; international motor show at Frankfurt; visit to the School of Fashion at Munich; diving championships; and international riding events.

results.title: Rome and Pompeii
results.brief_description: The magnificence or Rome and Pompeii as they were about 2,000 years ago is reconstructed before your eyes. See the Colosseum, as it stood, with 50,000 Romans applauding the bloody gladiator spectacles. Walk the Roman Forum in all its splendour. See the Circus Maximus where 150,000 cheered the chariot races. Gaze at the lavish lifestyles in both Rome and Pompeii - the baths, theatres, temples, palaces and shopping markets. Watch Neros Rome ablaze and Mount Vesuvius devastation of Pompeii, recreated as it might have happened.

results.title: The Wild bunch (S)
results.creator_credit: Sam Peckinpah, Phil Feldman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: In 1913, a gang known as “The Wild Bunch”, rode into a Texas border town disguised as U.S. soldiers. Silently they entered the railroad office and robbed it. Perched on the rooftops above was a ring of hired gunmen waiting for their prey. When the gang emerged they opened fire. An exciting, provocative and influential film that breathed new life into Westerns, it brings together an all-star cast of fine actors at the peak of their talents to play the band of magnificent losers in a dying, lawless West.

results.title: Eating Raoul
results.creator_credit: Paul Bartel, Anne Kimmel, International Classis, Quartet, Quartet Films and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Paul and Mary Bland, an endearingly middle-class couple, want to get out of their swinger-infested apartment building and open a nice little restaurant in the country. However, real estate is expensive and Paul has just lost his job. So, they take out a kinky ad and then knock off the rich swingers who answer it…Enter Raoul.

results.description: Paul and Mary Bland, an endearingly middle-class couple, want to get out of their swinger-infested apartment building and open a nice little restaurant in the country. However, real estate is expensive and Paul has just lost his job. So, they take out a kinky ad and then knock off the rich swingers who answer it…Enter Raoul.
description_for_label: Paul and Mary Bland, an endearingly middle-class couple, want to get out of their swinger-infested apartment building and open a nice little restaurant in the country. However, real estate is expensive and Paul has just lost his job. So, they take out a kinky ad and then knock off the rich swingers who answer it…Enter Raoul.

results.title: Shifting Sands: from sand to celluloid continued...
results.brief_description: This video contains six short films about the lives of Aboriginal Australians living in today’s society. “Tears”, directed by Ivan Sen, is the story of a teenage couple as they walk from their northern mission station to a bus stop and await a new life with the girl’s father, who perhaps doesn’t know they are coming and who probably doesn’t care anyway. “My colour, your kind”, directed by Danielle McLean, is the journey through and to uncertainty of an albino Aboriginal girl who escapes from a severe Catholic mission to trek barefoot in a nightie across the outback. “Passing through”, directed by Mark Olive, a young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past? “Promise”, directed by Mitch Torres, is the tale of an old woman overseeing her grand-daughter making damper when she is asked how it came to be that she was betrothed at a young age. “My bed, your bed”, directed by Erica Glynn, in an isolated desert community, the time has come for two young people promised to each other under traditional law to move in together. Things don’t run as smoothly as they might. “Grace”, directed by Wesley Enoch, Grace is a middle-aged woman, living a comfortable life but when she returns to the mission where she grew up for the funeral of her sister she is confronted by the family she never met.
